class VideoStream

Detailed Description

A port of the existing IPRE Scribbler Python code to C++.

The original authors of the python based code are Keith O'Hara and Doug Blank.

This class implements all of the needed methods and components for controlling a scribbler robot.

Author:
Richard Edwards, John Hoare

Member Function Documentation

void Scribbler::beep ( double  duration,
int  freq,
int  freq2 = 0 
)

Function for sending tones to the robot.

Parameters:
duration - time specified in seconds
freq - the frequency of the tone
freq2 - an optional second frequency, defaults to 0
void Scribbler::conf_rle_range ( unsigned char *  picture,
int  x1,
int  y1,
int  x2,
int  y2 
)

Used to configure the blob tracking feature within the robot, by providing a picture and a specifying the top left and bottom right corner of a bounding box.

The bounding box will the define the pixels of interest for configuring the desired pixel values.

Parameters:
picture - 256x192 RGB Image
x1 - top left bounding box corner x value.
y1 - top left bounding box corner y value.
x2 - bottom right bounding box corner x value.
y2 - bottom right bounding box corner y value.
void Scribbler::configureBlob ( int  y_low = 0,
int  y_high = 255,
int  u_low = 0,
int  u_high = 255,
int  v_low = 0,
int  v_high = 255,
int  smooth_thresh = 4 
)

Used to manually define the bounds for a blob configuration in YUV color space.

Note, this generally will not be used unless one wishes to write a different blob configuration other than the one provided by conf_rle_range.

Parameters:
y_low - Y Lower bound
y_high - Y Upper bound
u_low - U Lower bound
u_high - U Upper bound
v_low - V Lower bound
y_low - Y_lower bound
int Scribbler::connect (  )  [virtual]

Used to connect to the robot, and on use it will ask the user to specify the desired com port.

Returns:
returns a value less than 0 to indicate failure and a positive value greater than or equal to zero to indicate success.

Implements Robot.

int Scribbler::disconnect (  )  [virtual]

Attempts to disconnect from the robot.

Returns:
returns a value less than 0 to indicate failure, and a positive value greater than or equal to zero to indicate success.

Implements Robot.

void * Scribbler::get ( std::string  item,
std::vector< int >  position 
)

A general purpose get function which will query the specified item for data specified by the position vector.

Example: get("light", std::vector<int>(3,0)) : returns a pointer to a vector containing three readings from light sensor 0.

Returns:
The return value is a void * pointer, it is up to the caller to know which return value they are expecting and to cast accordingly.
void * Scribbler::get ( std::string  item,
std::vector< std::string >  position = std::vector<std::string>() 
)

A general purpose get function which will query the specified item for all data, or particular data specified by the position vector.

Example get("name") - return a pointer to the robot's name. get("info") - returns all information about the robot.

Parameters:
item - the desired item to query
position - a vector for issuing more detailed queries on an item.
Returns:
The return value is a void * pointer, it is up to the caller to know which return value they are expecting and to cast accordingly.
double Scribbler::getBattery (  ) 

Read the current voltage value for the batteries.

Returns:
The percentage of battery power remaining.
std::vector< int > Scribbler::getBlob (  ) 

Given that the blob tracking is configured, this function returns the number of pixels that match the specified blob and the x,y location related to said blob.

Returns:
A vector with the following data order: numpixels, x_location, y_location
int Scribbler::getBright ( std::string  value = ""  ) 

The camera has three different window's which it can use for returning light intensity.

getBright allows you to query a particular window for its intensity value.

Example: getBright("right")

Parameters:
value - The desired window to query.
Returns:
An integer represent the light intensity for the specified window.
std::vector< int > Scribbler::getData ( std::vector< int >  position = std::vector<int>()  ) 
Parameters:
position An optional vector used to specify desired byte indexes.
Returns:
This function returns either all 8 bytes stored on the robot, or a set of the data based on the input vector.

Example: A vector containing 1, 2, 3 will return the data bytes stored at index 1, 2, and 3.

std::vector< std::string > Scribbler::getInfo (  ) 

This returns information about the robot's dongle, firmware, and communication mode.

Returns:
The vector contains strings formated as item:value Example: fluke:2.7.8
std::vector< int > Scribbler::getLastSensors (  ) 

Every set command will read the values for all eleven on board robot sensors, and store them internally within a sensor array.

This, function returns a vector containing those previously read sensor values.

Returns:
A vector containing the robot's last sensor update. Order: Light 0, 1, 3 ir 4, 5 line 6, 7 stall 8
int Scribbler::getLight ( int  value  ) 

Used to query a specified light sensor located on the rear of the robot.

Example getLight(1)

Parameters:
value - The desired light sensor.
Returns:
A two byte integer representing the light reading from the specified light sensor.
int Scribbler::getLight ( std::string  value = "none"  ) 

Used to query a specified light sensor located on the rear of the robot.

Example: getLight("left")

Parameters:
value - The desired light sensor.
Returns:
An two byte integer representing the light reading from the specified light sensor.
std::vector< int > Scribbler::getLights (  ) 

Get the values of the light sensors.

Returns:
A vector of ints each one corresponding to a light sensor. 0 is left sensor, 1 is center, and 2 is right light sensor.
std::string Scribbler::getName (  ) 
Returns:
Returns the name of the robot.
int Scribbler::getObstacle ( int  value  ) 

Read the value for a specified dongle IR sensor.

Example: getObstacle(1)

Parameters:
value - The desired IR sensor to query.
Returns:
A value ranging from 0 - 6000. The larger the value the closer to an obstacle. However, the quality of the IR sensors decays over time. So it may be possible for the upper bound to be lower than 6000.
int Scribbler::getObstacle ( std::string  value = "none"  ) 

Reads the value for a specified dongle IR sensor.

Example: getObstacle("left")

Parameters:
value - The desired IR sensor to query.
Returns:
A value ranging from 0 - 6000. The larger the value the closer to an obstacle. However, the quality of the IR sensors decays over time. So it may be possible for the upper bound to be lower than 6000.
std::string Scribbler::getPassword (  ) 
Returns:
Returns the password stored on the robot.

int Scribbler::set ( std::string  item,
std::string  position,
double  value = 0 
)

A general purpose set function which allows you to setting an item at position to value, or setting an item to the value position.

Example: set(led, "front", 1) - sets front led to on set("name" "Scribby") - sets the robot's name to Scribby

Parameters:
item - the desired item
position - the desired position or value for item
value - the value for the desired item at position.
int Scribbler::set ( std::string  item,
int  position,
int  value = 0 
)

A general purpose set function which allows you to set an item at position on/off or set an item at position to value.

Example: set(led, 1, 0) - sets the center led to the off position. set(whitebalance, 1) - turns the camera's white balance on.

Parameters:
item - the desired item
position - the desired position or item value
value - the value for the desired item at position.
void Scribbler::setData ( int  position,
int  value 
)

Store a single byte value on the robot.

There are 8 byte values which can be accessed and modified.

Parameters:
position - index bounded on [0,7]
value - the desired value, bounded on [0,255]
void Scribbler::setEchoMode ( int  value  ) 

Used to turn the robot's echo mode on or off.

Parameters:
value - 0 for off, and 1 for on
void Scribbler::setForwardness ( int  direction  ) 

Used to set the robot's forward direction.

Parameters:
direction - 1 for fluke-forward and 0 for scribbler-forward
void Scribbler::setForwardness ( std::string  direction  ) 

Used to set the robot's forward direction.

The fluke can either be set to forward, or the light sensors on the rear of the robot can be set as the forward direction.

Parameters:
direction - the robot's desired forward direction. ("fluke-forward" or "scribbler-forward")
void Scribbler::setIRPower ( int  power  ) 

Used to set the power amount for the dongle's IR sensors.

Parameters:
power - desired power value bounded on [0,255]
void Scribbler::setLEDBack ( double  value  ) 

Used to set the back led to the specified value.

Parameters:
value - specify an intensity for the rear led. value is bounded on [0.0,1.0]
void Scribbler::setLEDFront ( int  value  ) 

Use to toggle the front led on or off.

Parameters:
value - 0 for off and 1 for on.
void Scribbler::setName ( std::string  newName  ) 

Changes the 16 byte name stored on the robot to the specified 16 byte name.

Parameters:
newName - A character string that isn't longer than 16 characters(does not count null character).
void Scribbler::setPassword ( std::string  password  ) 

Changes the 16 byte password stored on the robot to the new specified 16 byte password.

Parameters:
password - A character string that isn't longer than 16 characters(does not count null character).
void Scribbler::setSingleData ( int  position,
int  value 
)

Performs the same operations as setData, however using a different robot message, which doesn't require the resubmission of all 8 bytes.

Parameters:
position - index bounded on [0,7]
value - the desired value, bounded on [0,255]
void Scribbler::setWhiteBalance ( int  value  ) 

Used to turn the camera's white balance on or off.

Parameters:
value - 0 white balance off, 1 white balance on
Picture * Scribbler::takePicture ( std::string  type = "color"  ) 

Used to take pictures in the RGB and Gray Scale color space.

Also, once the blob tracking is configured it will return an image with the areas of interest in white, and the areas of non-interest in black.

Parameters:
type - Valid values, "color", "gray", and "blob"
Returns:
unsigned char array containing the image information.

Function for giving the robot a desired velocity.

Parameters:
amount - angular velocity [-1,1]

Implements Robot.
